title: Data Visualisation
text:
This page demonstrates how quantitative data can be visualised using Quarto and R.
The dataset represents the number of online purchases made per month over a six-month period.



A line chart is used because it clearly shows changes and trends over time.

title: Home
text:
My name is Kathy Mok and I am an Applied Computing (FinTech) student at Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT).
This website was created as part of the AI1001 assessment to demonstrate how to build and publish a personal website using Quarto and GitHub Pages.

title: Home
text:
Purpose of this website
The purpose of this website is to: - demonstrate basic Quarto website configuration - create and organise multiple web pages - apply Markdown formatting - publish the website online using GitHub Pages
Use the navigation bar above to view the other pages.

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text: Large Language Models (LLMs) are effective at reasoning but are not designed for structured tabular data used in click-through rate (CTR) prediction. Existing approaches rely on converting features into text prompts, leading to information loss and context-length constraints. This project proposes a Dense Feature Projection approach inspired by LLaVA, where compressed user features are projected directly into the LLM embedding space as dense tokens. Experiments on the Avazu dataset show that a compact 0.6B LLM achieves competitive CTR performance without textualising input features.

title: Project
text:
This page demonstrates how a project page can be structured in a Quarto website.
The example topic used here is a Shopee-related project, focusing on organising and analysing e-commerce related information.

title: Project
text:
Project objectives
The objectives of this project include: - understanding how data can be organised - applying basic analysis concepts - presenting results clearly in written form

title: Project
text:
What the project involved

identifying relevant information such as purchase details and categories
summarising information into meaningful groups
reflecting on the workflow and analysis process

title: Project
text:
Key learning point
A key learning point from this project is that clear organisation and presentation are just as important as the analysis itself.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: I used Claude as a GenAI tool to support me in completing this assessment.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: I used Claude as a GenAI tool to support me in completing this assessment.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
How GenAI helped me
it helped me understand how to create and configure a Quarto website, including setting up the project structure and rendering pages correctly for GitHub Pages.
It was also useful in troubleshooting technical issues related to Git and GitHub, such as resolving push errors.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Benefits of using GenAI
Using GenAI reduced the time spent on technical difficulties and helped me focus more on understanding the workflow and requirements of the assessment. It also improved the clarity and organisation of my website content.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Future use of GenAI
In the future, I believe GenAI can support my studies and work by assisting with debugging, learning new tools, and improving documentation. However, it should be used responsibly, with careful validation of outputs.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Story Behind This Visualisation
This visualisation was created as part of a student project analyzing personal spending patterns. The data shows:

Holiday spike in November-December (Black Friday and holiday shopping)
Post-holiday decline in January (budget recovery)
Stable baseline in August-October (5-8 purchases per month)

The line chart effectively shows the temporal trend and makes patterns immediately visible.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Data Summary


Total Purchases: 55 


Average Monthly Purchases: 9.17 


Highest Month: Dec with 15 purchases


Lowest Month: Aug with 5 purchases

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text: Large Language Models (LLMs) are effective at reasoning but are not designed for structured tabular data used in click-through rate (CTR) prediction. Existing approaches rely on converting features into text prompts, leading to information loss and context-length constraints. This project proposes a Dense Feature Projection approach inspired by LLaVA, where compressed user features are projected directly into the LLM embedding space as dense tokens. Experiments on the Avazu dataset show that a compact 0.6B LLM achieves competitive CTR performance without textualising input features.

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text:
2 Introduction
CTR prediction is a core task in recommender systems. Traditional CTR models handle structured data well but lack reasoning capabilities, while LLMs excel at reasoning but expect text input. Bridging this gap remains a challenge.

2.1 Problem Statement
Prompt-based LLM CTR methods suffer from: - Context-length limits that truncate user histories - Weak preservation of feature interactions when using text


2.2 Objectives
This project aims to: - Avoid textual conversion of CTR features - Encode features as dense latent representations - Project these representations into the LLM embedding space - Evaluate performance on a standard CTR dataset

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text:
3 Methodology
User features are first compressed using an SFG-inspired encoder to capture feature interactions. An MLP projector then maps the compressed features into the LLM embedding space. These projected embeddings are concatenated with a short task prompt and processed by the LLM for CTR prediction.

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text:
4 Dataset
The Avazu CTR dataset is used. Features are normalised into a fixed schema of 21 categorical fields and a binary click label. Missing values are padded to ensure consistent input dimensions.

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text:
5 Experiments
Experiments are conducted using Qwen LLMs (0.6B and 1.7B parameters) under different training strategies. Models are evaluated using AUC and log loss.

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text:
6 Results
The best-performing configuration is the 0.6B model trained end-to-end, achieving competitive results compared to generative CTR baselines, while requiring no feature textualisation.

title: LLaVA-Inspired Dense Feature Projection for LLM-Based CTR Prediction
text:
7 Conclusion
This project demonstrates that LLMs can be applied to CTR prediction using dense projected tabular features. The results suggest that dense feature projection is a viable alternative to prompt-based approaches and provides a foundation for future LLM-based recommender systems.
